feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A calendar system is not a physical object; wall calendars and apps are its representations.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Calendar systems are invented and maintained by human cultures.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — While inspired by astronomical cycles, their structure is synthetic.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Calendar systems evolve over time and differ by culture.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — Its structure is formal and conceptual, not architectural.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — Calendars are visually rendered to support their use.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — The concept of a calendar is not made of matter.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It has no reactive or dynamic function in itself.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Created for coordinating events and structuring time.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — Does not autonomously generate results; output depends on interpretation.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — Encodes logic, but is not a processor.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Its use does not involve internal transformation.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — The system itself is static; interaction is through media.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — Can be integrated but is not inherently part of another system.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires human use to function.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Helpful but not structurally essential to a system’s operation.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Uses symbolic structures to represent temporal information.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Expresses dates, durations, and cycles to others.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Built on formalized leap-year rules, cycles, and sequences.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Days form weeks, weeks form months, months form years.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Used to guide planning, rituals, and deadlines.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — The system does not encode itself or refer to its own principles.
feedback.Temporal: Included — Its entire domain is the structure of time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Calendars differ by religion, culture, and purpose.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Calendars are culturally maintained artifacts.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Institutionalized by religious or governmental bodies.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not specific to personal or group identity.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — While adopted officially, calendar logic is not formally enforced everywhere.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Core knowledge taught in basic education worldwide.
feedback.Visible: Included — Always instantiated in a visible form for use.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Varies across geopolitical and cultural contexts.

encoding_notes: This encoding treats the calendar as a symbolic, logic-based, culturally constructed abstraction designed for temporal organization. It is not a physical object or a processor, but a framework used to coordinate and guide behavior within human systems. The uht_code reflects its highly abstract and socially embedded nature with minimal functional operation.
